title: 115_hr479
content: The Act titled "North Korea State Sponsor of Terrorism Designation Act of 2017" requires a report on designating the government of North Korea as a state sponsor of terrorism. The United States designated North Korea as a state sponsor of terrorism in 1988, but this designation was rescinded in 2008 after commitments to dismantle its nuclear weapons program. However, North Korea has not upheld these commitments, posing a threat to the US and global nonproliferation efforts. The Government of North Korea has harbored members of the Japanese Red Army since a 1970 hijacking and continues to support terrorist attacks by Hezbollah against Israel. In 2010, North Korean officials were convicted of attempting to assassinate a dissident in South Korea. In 2015, South Korea blamed North Korea for a cyber attack on nuclear power plants. In 2015, the FBI attributed a cyber attack on Sony Pictures Entertainment to North Korea. The FBI attributed a cyber attack on Sony Pictures Entertainment to North Korea, leading to threats against theaters showing "The Interview". Malaysian authorities accused North Korea of poisoning Kim Jong-nam with VX nerve agent. Congress believes North Korea meets criteria for state sponsor of terrorism. The Secretary of State must make a determination within 90 days. The Secretary of State must determine if North Korea meets criteria for state sponsor of terrorism within 90 days. The determination will be submitted in unclassified form, with a possible classified annex. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "appropriate congressional committees" as the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations and the House Committee on Foreign Affairs. "North Korea" refers to the Government of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. "State sponsor of terrorism" is a country that has repeatedly supported acts of international terrorism. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 3, 2017. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
